awd_titl_txt: Protein Glycosylation in Pollen Tube Growth and Fertilization
awd_abstract_narration:
The majority of food crops are flowering plants that require successful fertilization to produce grains and fruits. Fertilization requires pollen to land on the female flower and form a pollen tube, a rapidly elongating single-celled projection which grows through the female tissue, in some cases for several centimeters. This pollen tube is able to reorient its growth in response to chemical guidance cues to deliver the male reproductive cells to the female. The pollen tube, like other plant cells is surrounded by a cell wall and cell expansion requires the proper secretion of new cell wall material that is specifically targeted to the specialized, flexible cell wall at the growing tip. The internal secretory machinery and the cell wall must be appropriately coordinated with each other and with the direction of elongation for successful sustained growth. Despite the importance of this process for agricultural production, a major gap exists in our understanding of how the external cell wall and the intracellular secretory apparatus coordinate to maintain a stable but responsive tip region over time. This project will elucidate the linkage between these two compartments using genetics, biochemistry and cell imaging approaches. The research will also support the training of graduate and undergraduate students. Research activities will be integrated into an introductory plant biology lab course giving students an authentic research experience. In addition, the project will provide interactive, hands-on activities to the general public in collaboration with the University of Michigan Museum of Natural History. This project was co-funded by the Plant, Fungal and Microbial Developmental Mechanisms Program in the Division of Integrative Organismal Systems and the Cellular Dynamics and Function Program in the Division of Molecular and Cellular Biosciences. 

Flowering plant fertility depends on the sustained rapid elongation of pollen tubes and their ability to reorient growth to effectively target receptive ovules. Proper pollen tube elongation requires hydroxyproline (hyp) O-arabinosylation, the posttranslational addition of arabinose sugar chains to hydroxyprolines. Arabinosyltransferase mutants exhibit shorter, wider and sometimes branched pollen tubes, suggesting impaired tip-region stability. The secretion required for pollen tube elongation depends on the highly dynamic F-actin structures at the pollen tube tip. F-actin organization is controlled, in part, by the nucleation activity of class 1 formin homology proteins. The extracellular domains of these proteins contain predicted arabinosylation motifs which have been implicated in interaction with the cell wall. This project will test the hypothesis that the pollen tube cell wall and actin cytoskeleton are coordinated via hyp O-arabinosylation of the class 1 formin homology proteins, limiting their actin organizing activity to appropriate cortical domains though interaction with the overlying cell wall.  Altered cell wall polarity and actin organization will be assayed in the mutants and wild type. The in vivo glycosylation status of the class 1 formins will be determined for three important members of this protein family, including two known regulators of pollen tube actin. Furthermore, the effect of the extracellular domains on protein mobility and localization in the pollen tube will be determined. This research will establish an essential point of connection between two major cell components required for pollen tube polarization and growth.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Plant cells are surrounded by a carbohydrate-rich cell wall which determines the shape of the cell and provides essential structural support to it. The cell wall is a complex composite of several distinct polymers with varying mechanical and biochemical properties that serve different function within the wall. The organization of the cell wall varies between cell types, environmental conditions and over developmental time. Furthermore, as cells grow, the cell wall must expand to accommodate the increase in cell volume, but still maintain sufficient mechanical strength to prevent cell rupture from the high pressure of the cytoplasm within the cell. How is the cell wall assembled and remodeled to allow for cell growth? This project worked to address these questions using the pollen tube as a model system. Pollen tubes are single cells and are among the fastest growing cells in nature as they race to fertilize a limited number of ovules within flowers. Pollen tubes also grow by "tip-growth" where one specific region of the cell is actively expanding while the rest of the cell does not. This leads to a highly polarized organization of the pollen tube. The tip region is covered with a specialized cell wall that is rich in flexible polymers while the rest of the pollen tube is surrounded by a cell wall rich in rigid, reinforcing polymers. Internally, the cell is also polarized, particularly the actin cytoskeleton. Individual actin proteins are able to assemble into long filaments, thick cables and fine meshwork structures depending on the needs of the cell. In pollen tubes, actin is polarized with a fine meshwork in the tip region and thick cables running the length of the pollen tube. This organization helps target the secretion of internally synthesized new cell wall material to the tip where it is incorporated into the tip cell wall, allowing the pollen tube to expand. The actin cytoskeleton is highly dynamic. If the pollen tube needs to change the direction of its growth as it searches for an ovule, the actin cytoskeleton is re-oriented, subtly changing the direction of secretion and allowing the pollen tube to turn. For continued growth, the polarization of the cell wall and the actin cytoskeleton must be maintained.

The formin homology proteins are key regulators of the actin cytoskeleton. In plants, the class I formin homology proteins also have an extracellular domain in addition to the internal portion of the protein that regulates actin organization. This project tested the hypothesis that the extracellular portion of these proteins interact with the cell wall and help coordinate the cell wall and the actin cytoskeleton in growing pollen tubes. The class I formin homology proteins of the model plant Arabidopsis thaliana, AtFH3 and AtFH5 are known to be important regulators of actin during pollen tube growth. While AtFH3 is localized throughout the pollen tube periphery, AtFH5 is limited to the tip region. We found that the extracellular domains of these proteins are glycosylated (modified by the addition of sugars), similar to cell wall proteins with AtFH3 carrying large sugar side chains and AtFH5 having smaller types of sugar chains. Furthermore, these differences in glycosylation alter the mobility of AtFH3 and AtFH5 within the pollen tube. AtFH3 has very low mobility. Once it arrives at the cell periphery, the protein stays in one location. In contrast, AtFH5 was more mobile. Furthermore, when the glycosylation of these proteins was disrupted, the actin cytoskeleton structure was also disrupted, demonstrating that these sugars are important for class I formin function. Therefore, the glycosylation of the extracellular domain of the class I formins is key to keeping their actin regulating activity in the right position within the pollen tube.

In addition to the scientific work of this project, we also participated in several broader outreach activities, including working with the University of Michigan's Museum of Natural History on several scientist spotlight events, presenting interactive activities about our research to the general public.
